newsitem.title: UK: Jaguar advertises its cars on outside of planes.
newsitem.headline: Jaguar advertises its cars on outside of planes.

text.p: Jaguar, the sports car company, launched an unusual advertising campaign on Wednesday by paying an airline to have huge jaguars painted on its planes.
Jaguar Ltd said it expected about 40 million people over the next year to see the green "big cat" mascot on the fuselage of Ryanair, a British-based airline.
"It's tremendous value for money," Colin Cook, Jaguar's director of corporate affairs, told Reuters.
Jaguar paid an estimated 100,000 pounds for Ryanair, an Irish-owned carrier which flies throughout Britain and Ireland, to carry the huge ads on its Boeing 737 aircraft.
Jaguar, which was bought by Ford Motor Co, America's second biggest carmaker, in 1989, said it had wanted to find a "new and innovative promotional programme".
Ryanair flies 13 routes between Ireland and Britain, and plans to fly to continental Europe in the spring.
In June Marketing magazine said Ryanair had offered the exterior of its fleet of 11 Boeing 737's for hire to potential advertisers for 120,000 pounds for one year.
Ryanair said it was the first British-based carrier to carry ads on planes and was following the example of other airlines in the United States that had acted as "billboards in the sky".
The new ad campaign is meant to promote the "leaper", Jaguar's XK8 high performance sports car, which was due to fill showrooms this month and which costs over $65,000.
Jaguar and other sports car makers are struggling to attract consumers in with what industry experts say is a dwindling market.
"Sports cars are a dying and shrinking market..." Peter Schmidt, with Automotive Industry Data, told Reuters at the Paris car show a few weeks ago.
"...people's tastes are changing in Europe and America. They don't want to flaunt their wealth," he said.
